Silvia's father does not have a specific job but her mother works in the city to help the family. Endang is applying for a loan to help pay for the education of Silvia.

Silvia hopes that this loan will alleviate the burden of thinking of her grandmother and her parents. Silvia can focus and keep her spirit up to continue her studies, because she does not have to worry that the study will be disrupted because of the cost. And ideals can be realized as a professional accountant. In the picture are Silvia and Endang, her grandmother.

loans.use: To pay education fees at a vocational school

loans.name: Mor

texts.fr:
Les besoins liées à son véhicule, Mor, un chauffeur de 40 ans, qui a une expérience de plus de 15 ans dans ce métier ; vient solliciter l’appui de l’IMCEC  pour renouveler un crédit  à hauteur de 50000F CFA afin de pouvoir repeindre son véhicule.
Monsieur Mor est marié et père de famille. Il gère sa petite famille avec les recettes de son activité.
Il envisage  d’acheter un autre véhicule pour augmenter ses revenus.
texts.en:
Mor, a 40-year-old driver, has more than 15 years of experience in his job, and his needs are tied to his vehicle. He has just sought support from IMCEC to renew a loan amounting to 50,000 FCFA in order to be able to repaint his vehicle.
Mr. Mor is married and the father of a family. He manages his small family with the income from his business.
He foresees buying another vehicle to increase his income.

loans.use: To buy paint to repaint his taxi.

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr:
Khady  est la technicienne de surface d’un de nos guichets. Elle est aussi une habituée de l’IMCEC, car en dehors de son métier, elle fait du commerce de divers. Seulement pour cette fois ci, elle sollicite un crédit de 50000F FCFA pour régler des problèmes sociaux.
Khady est mariée et avec ses revenus, appui sa famille dans les besoins quotidiens.
texts.en:
Khady is the cleaner at one of our branches. She is also a regular at IMCEC, since she runs a business selling various items outside of her main job. Just for this one time, she is seeking a loan of 50,000 FCFA to settle some social issues.
Khady is married and supports her family's daily needs with her income.

loans.use: To settle a social need.

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr:
Madame Fatou est une dame de 52 ans qui s’active dans le petit commerce depuis plus de 15 ans maintenant. Elle est divorcée  et vit avec son frère qui se trouve être en France .Elle fait de la vente de produits alimentaires tels que : de l’huile de palme, de l’eau de citron, du poisson fumé et séché…
Fatou est divorcée et se gère elle même.
texts.en:
Ms. Fatou is a 52-year-old woman who has been involved in her own small business for over 15 years now. She is divorced and lives with her brother, who is currently in France. She sells food items such as palm oil, lemon water, smoked and dried fish, etc.
Fatou is divorced and provides for herself.

loans.use: To buy various food items for resale (palm oil, lemon water, dried and smoked fish)

loans.name: Dieumbe

texts.fr:
Madame Dieumbe, agée de 36 ans possède un restaurant fast Food près de là  ou elle loge ; activité qu’elle exerce depuis  plus de 5 ans déjà. Elle n’est pas une novice dans le crédit car elle a eu à faire parti d’un groupement de femme. Maintenant que ses affaires vont plus régulières, elle est sorti du groupement  pour pouvoir bénéficier d’un montant supérieur que d’habitude. C e crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra de se ravitailler en denrées alimentaires (viande, huile, pomme de terre et autres ingrédients qui entrent dans la cuisson. 
Elle gère ses propres besoins et appui son époux dans la dépense quotidienne.
Elle désire agrandir davantage  son exploitation avec l’aide d’une Institution financière comme l’IMCEC.
texts.en:
Ms. Dieumbe is 36 years old and owns a fast food restaurant near where she lives; she has run this business for more than five years already. She is not new to microfinance, as she used to belong to a women's loan group. Now that her business is running more regularly, she has left the group in order to be able to benefit from a larger loan amount than previously. The loan she is seeking will allow her to restock her business with foodstuffs (meat, oil, potatoes, and other ingredients used in cooking).
She provides for herself and supports her husband with the daily expenses.
She wants to further expand her business with the help of a financial institution like IMCEC.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs for her restaurant (oil, meat, potatoes, ingredients)

loans.name: Magaye

texts.fr:
Monsieur Magaye est un tailleur qui possède son propre atelier depuis 2000. Il est  marié et père de famille. Il possède des machines à coudre et veut augmenter son parc avec le crédit qu’elle sollicite.
Il s’occupe de la dépense quotidienne de sa famille.
Et veut dans l’avenir élargir son activité à un niveau plus élevé.
texts.en:
Mr. Magaye is a tailor who has owned his own workshop since 2000. He is married and is the father of a family.  He owns some sewing machines and wants to increase his stock with the loan he is seeking.
He takes care of his family's daily expenses.
In the future, he wants to expand his business and bring it to a higher level.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine for his work.

loans.name: Juharti

texts.en:
Juharti opened a shop at home to help improve her family's economy. Her husband is a laborer whose income is uncertain and depends on the presence or absence of work. Juharti is very concerned about the future of their children, especially their education.Juharti requested a loan from Kiva in order to finance their children's schooling.

Sofyan is the third child in the family. His two older brothers are married but they still do not own their own homes. Sofyan really wants to keep learning, because he wants to have a bright future and become a professional accountant. In the picture, Sofyan appears with Juharti, his mother.

loans.use: To pay education fees at a vocational school

loans.name: Olga Marina

texts.es: Doña Olga, tiene 55 años de edad, reside en el municipio de nueva Frontera, Santa Bárbara, junto a su esposo y sus 3 hijos. La señora tiene 10 años de haber establecido el negocio de pulpería donde vende productos de la canasta básica familiar, como arroz, pan, manteca, frijoles, abarrotes, harina, refrescos, lácteos, etc. para mantener estable su negocio quiere invertir otro préstamo, para eso solicita este préstamo de 5,000 Lempiras para mantener siempre surtido y variedad de productos alimenticios que demandan sus clientes. Su meta es tener un local en un buen lugar y con buena clientela.
texts.en:
Olga is 55, and lives in the municipality of Nueva Frontera, Santa Bárbara department, with her husband and their three children. 

She set up her small grocery store ten years ago, and sells basic household products, such as rice, bread, lard, beans, groceries, flour, soft drinks, dairy products, etc. 

In order to keep her business stable, she wants to invest another loan. That is why she is applying for this loan of 5,000 lempiras, in order to always stay supplied with a variety of food products that her customers ask for. 

Her goal is to have a shop in a good location with a good clientele.

loans.use: To buy goods such as dairy products, soft drinks, bread, sugar, flour, lard, etc., for supplying her store.

loans.name: Sharif

texts.en:
Sharif is 51 years old and married. He sells food items to earn a living. He has his own shop and sells high-quality food items such as bread, butter and conserves (jams) for his customers. He has been in the business for four years. 

Through financial support from his brothers, he has managed to grow his business. He has additional income from selling dried fruits. One time a month he exports his goods to Russia. His brothers and his wife help him with business. 

He dreams of expanding his business and becoming prosperous in the future. He needs a loan of $1,500 to buy food items for widening the assortment of goods to sell. He will look forward to your help.

loans.use: To buy food products for widening the assortment of goods to sell.

loans.name: Claudia

texts.en: Claudia is 57 years old, married with three children and lives in the Philippines. Claudia  has a food/retail shop or sari-sari store that sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products and beverages. She had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for  6,000 PHP to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages. Claudia has been a member of HSPFI since 1998. In the future, Claudia hopes to improve her business to support the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Sartono

texts.en:
Sartono gets seasonal employment with an uncertain income and the work is uncertain. His wife opened a shop at home to help the economic situation of the family. However, the results are still far from enough. Sartono has four children, Soimah is the last child and hopes to stay in school. Sartono applied  for a loan through Kiva's Student Loan program  to help Soimah complete her studies at a vocational school.

Soimah has three siblings and she is eager to continue her education at a vocational school. Soimah wants to make her parents happy and achieve her goal of being a designer of clothes. With a loan from Kiva, this is now certain. In the picture are Soimah and Sartono, her father.

loans.use: To pay education fees at a vocational  school

loans.name: Salimin

texts.en:
Salimin is a maker of bricks with a daily income of less than 30 USD. In the rainy season, there is no income because Salimin can not make bricks. With a situation like this, it is clearly difficult to finance all four of his children's school expenses.  Finally, Salimin applied for a loan through Kiva's Student Loan program. He hopes to help Wiwin, his daughter, finish school at the vocational school.

Wiwin is number two of four siblings. Her goal is to become a designer of dresses. With a loan from Kiva, she hopes to finish school and help her parents and younger siblings. In the picture, Wiwin appears with Salimin, her father.

loans.use: To pay education fees at a vocational school

loans.name: Kamisem

texts.en:
Kamisem works as a casual laborer. Her income is very minimal. If one day Kamisem does not work, then that day she does not get money. If Kamisem is experiencing pain, then she cannot get income. With these conditions, Kamisem is greatly saddened about the education of their children. Therefore, Kamisem is applying for a loan through Kiva's student loan program, in order to allow Sulastri to finish school.

Sulastri lives in a hilly, dry area with damaged roads and houses that are quite a distance away from the school. She attends a vocational school. She aspires to be a computer expert. Sulastri has a four-year-old brother. She hopes, through the help of the Kiva student loan program, to help ease the burden on her mother. In the picture, Sulastri and Kamisem her mother.

loans.use: To pay education fees at a vocational school

loans.name: Jamiyah

texts.en:
Farm labor is Jamiyah's job. She's the mother of one student, Syaefudin, at the vocational school. Her earnings as a laborer are not enough to cover all the needs of her family. Jamiyah and Syaefudin have concerns about the son's education. Jamiyah hopes to follow the student loan program, to fund Syaefudin's studies so he can finish school.

Syaefudin aspires to be a computer programmer. He still wants to attend the vocational school. He is hoping the Kiva student loan program can help him to finish school so he can quickly get a job and help his family. In the picture, Syaefudin and Jamiyah his mother.

loans.use: To pay education fees at a vocational school

loans.name: Sivorn's Group

texts.en: Sivorn, 33, is a mother of two sons who currently are working at a local organization in the community. She has been involved in producing rice wine as her major source of income. She also raises pigs and sells hashed roll meat wrapped in banana leaves (the most popular dessert in Battambang for Cambodians) for extra income. Sivorn's group consists of two female members; she is the group leader and she is a first-time borrower with VisionFund while the other member is a sixth-time borrower. She and her partner are seeking a new loan of  500,000 KHR and 300,000 KHR, respectively. As the group leader, she will use her loan portion to buy materials for producing her rice wine, including yeast and rice. She expects to make more income so as to improve her living condition.

loans.use: to buy materials for producing her rice wine.

loans.name: Rabia's Group

texts.en:
Rabia is a 48-year-old, hard-working housewife with three sons and three daughters and is a resident of Rawalpindi, Pakistan. For the past five years, her husband has been driving a van, which is the only source of income for his family.

Rabia is a member of three-person lending group that has requested a loan from Kiva partner BRAC Pakistan to expand her husband's transportation business by buying a new van. This will not only help expand their transportation business but will also help increase their monthly income. She is very hopeful that the loan will be productive so that they can meet the basic necessities of their family and provide education to their children.

loans.use: to buy a new van for her husband's transportation business.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es: Doña Francisca tiene 63 años de edad, soltera, tiene 3 hijos, vive en el municipio Nueva Frontera, Santa Bárbara junto a dos hijos. Anteriormente se dedicaba a la venta de productos alimenticios de manera ambulante y hace 6 años decidió establecerlo en su casa donde vende azúcar, pan, café, manteca, refrescos, jugos, etc. está solicitando un segundo préstamo por 15,000 Lempiras con el cual va tener más surtido de productos como azúcar, manteca, sal, arroz, refrescos, jugos etc. con esta inversión va poder ofrecer variedad de productos a sus clientes y va incrementar los ingresos. Su meta es seguir obteniendo sus ingresos, mejorar su calidad de vida y ayudar a su familia.
texts.en:
Francisca is 63, single, and has three children. She lives with two of her children, in the town of Nueva Frontera, in Santa Bárbara department. 

Previously, she sold food products as a street vendor, and six years ago decided to set up a store in her home, where she sells sugar, bread, coffee, lard, soft drinks, juices, etc. 

She is applying for a second loan of 15,000 lempiras, with which she is going to have a larger selection of products such as sugar, lard, salt, rice, soft drinks, juices, etc. With this investment, she is going to be able to offer product variety to her customers, and is going to add to her income.

Her goal is to continue earning her income, improving her quality of life, and helping her family.

loans.use: To buy products such as sugar, coffee, lard, bread, soft drinks, juices, etc. for stocking her store.

loans.name: Lestari

texts.en:
Lestari is a mother who must feed three children alone. Her husband has long since left Lestari. Lestari works just as a domestic servant, with a very limited income. Lestari does not want her children to drop out of school. She expects that her son Thomas wants to finish quickly. Lestari hopes, with the student loan from Kiva, she can pay for Thomas to finish school.

Thomas is a pupil at a vocational school. Thomas lives in a hilly and barren area. Thomas hopes that the student loan program can help ease the burden on his mother. Thomas hopes his ideal of becoming an expert in the field of computers can be achieved. In the picture, Thomas and Lestari his mother.

loans.use: To pay education fees at a vocational school

loans.name: Karwan

texts.en:
Karwan works as a laborer making uncertain earnings each month. Karwan has three children, two of whom did not attend school because of economic limitations. Karwan hopes Trinov can go to school, because he's the only hope. Karwan is hoping for help from the student loan program of Kiva.

Trinov is a student at a vocational school. He aspires to be a computer technician. Trinov has a fear of not completing school. He is thankful for the Kiva student loan program, which can help him finish school. In the picture, Trinov and Karwan his father.

loans.use: To pay education fees at a vocational school

loans.name: Mary Helma

texts.en: Mary Helma has been a seamstress for more than 20 years. She is married and has two children, both married. She is a hard-working woman who wants to get ahead in life. Mary Helma is really thankful to God because since joining the program of ASKI, she has been able to improve the quality of her sewn dresses which has made her business grow. Now she has a lot of customers. She had started to borrow additional capital in 2005. Her profits were used to buy a single motorcycle, which is useful in the delivery of her finished products. Mary Helma maintains her good track record to date and is asking for another loan amount of 20,000 PHP. This amount will be used to buy garments, thread and a zigzag machine to make her work easier and to be able to produce more dresses and curtains to sell. Mary Helma is looking forward to the approval of her requested loan amount.

loans.use: to buy garments, thread and a zigzag machine for her sewing business.

loans.name: Yen's Group

texts.en: Yen, originally from a rural area of Dambae District of Kampong Cham Province, is a 42-year-old mother of one dependent son who is still in school. To support her household, she has been planting cassava and sugar cane for five years and manages to earn about 13,000 KHR per day. She can save about 3,000 KHR after daily expenses. Yen's group consists of two female members who are currently second-time borrowers. The original loan, which has been paid back with success, has helped her to sustain her business and improve her living condition. Now, she and her partner are seeking a new loan of 300,000 KHR and 1,000,000 KHR, respectively. She, as the group leader, will use her loan portion to buy fertilizer to boost her crops. She hopes to grow it timely and increase her income.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to boost her crops

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en: Fredrick is a hardworking businessman who does tailoring to earn a living. He operates his business in a conducive environment with potential customers. He had previously acquired a loan from Faulu Kenya which helped him to grow his business and he was also able to employ two people. He has also learnt how to manage his business since he has been trained in business management. He dreams of expanding his business in the future. Fredrick has requested for a loan of 60,000 KES to buy a tailoring machine.

loans.use: To buy a tailoring machine

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul is applying for his second loan from KADET LTD after repaying the previous loan successfully. Paul will use the loan to buy a heifer and animal feed. He will also boost his wife’s green grocer business. With the anticipated profit from the business he will educate his child. His hopes and dreams are to buy a taxi car and improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: To buy a heifer and animal feed

loans.name: Tajamul

texts.en:
Tajamul Bano is a 56-year-old married women who enjoys doing the work of hand embroidery. She started doing this work with her daughters. Her embroidery patterns are very popular in her territory. Due to increased demand of her embroidery designs, she is indulging other women in her business.
She has two daughters and two sons. Her husband is not in a good physical shape to support her family. She is motivated to provide her family with the basic necessities of life including food, clothes and education. 
In order to meet the growing demand for embroidery she needs to engage some more women. Now she requested a loan of Rs.20,000 from Kashf foundation. In this way she can manage to buy more frames, needles and threads of different colors which will help in generating more income. She hopes to have a good experience with this new loan.

loans.use: To buy more frames, needles and threads of different colors.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stock of canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Tita

texts.en:
Tita is a small entreprenuer who aims for business progression. She only sells personal and home products such as detergents and cosmetics for profits. She had been doing it for over five years now and earns P3,000 each month from her business. It goes for their meals and daily allowances of her children. She is now 46 years old, married and had five children. She is asking for additional capital of P10,000 to revolve in the business. She will buy more perfumes, colognes, toothpaste and detergent soap to sell. 

Someday, with good profits from the business, she will earn income to invest in a hog raising business. This will help diversify her business and achieve the desired success for the family.

loans.use: to buy more perfumes, colognes, toothpaste, and detergent soap to sell

loans.name: Harsiti

texts.en:
Harsiti is a day laborer with a minimal income. Lasiman, Harsiti's husband, also works as a laborer with a monthly income of less than 50 USD. And that's when Harsiti and her husband have a job for a long time. With very little income, she must pay for her three children. With this loan from Kiva, Harsiti wants Yuli to complete her studies at a vocational school.

Yuli wants to be a professional accountant, but due to family economic factors, she is very concerned that she won't finish school. Because there is a Student Loan program from Kiva, Yuli is very happy. Yuli hopes she will be able to complete school. In the picture, Yuli appears with Harsiti, her mother.

loans.use: To pay education fees at a vocational school

loans.name: Mustarja

texts.en:
Mustarja is only a laborer breaking stones and his wife is an agricultural laborer. Because Mustarja is elderly, he cannot work properly, so his wife is now helping him as a stone-breaking laborer. However, Mustarja does not get customers every day. Sometimes for a week or even two weeks, there are no customers. Because of an uncertain economic future, Mustarja worries about the education of his son Saefal. He hopes that Kiva's Student Loan program can help with his children's education.

Saefal is the sixth of six children and attends vocational school. With a loan from Kiva, he hopes to finish school and help his parents and siblings. In the picture are Mustarja, his wife and his son, Saefal.

loans.use: To pay education fee at a vocational school

loans.name: Sunarto

texts.en:
Sunarto works as a laborer-brick maker with revenues of less than 3 USD a day. On rainy days, Sunarto cannot make any money because he must stop making bricks. His wife died and left three-year-old twins named Anjarsari and Anjaswati. Sunarto must work alone to meet their daily needs. Student Loans from Kiva help Sunarto to help Anjaswati and Anjarsari finish school.

Anjaswati has a twin sister named Anjarsar, and three other siblings. Now, Anjaswati just graduated from junior high school and wants to go to vocational school so that she can reach her goal of being a clothes designer.. She  is very grateful to Kiva for the student loan program and hopefully she can finish school. In the picture, Anjaswati appears with Sunarto, her father.

loans.use: To pay education fees at a vocational school

loans.name: Denis

texts.en:
Denis is 35 years old and lives in the town of Najera in the Kampala West region of Uganda. He is married and has four children, with three of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Denis has been working hard to manage his butcher shop, which sells meat.

To help expand his business, Denis has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to expand his business by purchasing more meat to butcher, and will help Denis to generate greater profits and to improve his family's status. Denis hopes that in the future, he will be able to open up more businesses within the locality.

Denis is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP.) The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Denis who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more meat to butcher .

loans.name: Aem's Group

texts.en:
Living in a rural area located in the Sangke district of Battambang province, Aem is 53 years old and married. He has five children, who have their own employment. To make a living, he has been planting garlic and chilies for almost 30 years and countering low yield from his business, which has affected his family’s income.

Aem received his first loan seven cycles ago and he completely paid back the loans. The past loans from VisionFund have helped his family significantly improve its living and afford to buy a plot of farmland. Now he can earn about 32,100 KHR per day from his current business. Now he and his member who is just with VisionFund this loan cycle are requesting a loan of 800,000 KHR and 100,000 KHR respectively. As the leader, he wants to use his portion to buy fertilizers and seeds for his farmland and use a portion of it to spend for land plowing. He hopes to increase his crop yields so as to improve his family’s living standard.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds for his farmland.

loans.name: Domitilah

texts.en:
Domitilah is 26 years old and is married with two children. She operates a retail shop to earn a living and has been engaged in this business for two years. She has requested a loan of 10,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy sugar, green grams (mung beans), and maize flour.

Domitilah previously received a loan from Faulu Kenya that helped her grow her business. With the income she generated, she was able to build a house for her family. She dreams of operating a wholesale business in the future.

loans.use: To buy sugar, green grams, and maize flour.

loans.name: Ponciana

texts.en: Ponciana is 51 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is widowed with three children. Ponciana has a food/retail shop, or sari-sari store, that buys and sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products and beverages. She had this business for 21 years. She requested a loan for  4,000 PHP to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages. Ponciana has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Ponciana hopes to improve her business for the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Yonisa

texts.en:
This is Yonisa, 53, a resident of Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Jose, who is a salesman and a mother to her children. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Yonisa maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 2,000 PHP in sales every week.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 12,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Yonisa hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to have a good life for her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
Phan (in the photo) is a widow. She lives with her daughter and three grandchildren in a village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City, across the Mekong River. Her daughter used to be a weaver, but she quit the weaving business and is now a cleaner for a company.

Phan is a weaver, and she supplements her income with a rice-farming business when farming season comes. All of Phan’s grandchildren are in school. One has finished his baccalaureate and wants to continue his bachelor's degree at IT University. Hence, Phan has decided to apply for a loan to pay his school fees.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her grandson.

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en: Teopista lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with five children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of two additional family members. She sells cereals like beans, maize, and ground nuts at the market. She sells her products on a wholesale and retail basis. She has been in business for the last seven years. She works six days a week. She has requested for a 1,200,000 UGX loan from MCDT – SACCO to buy bags of beans, maize and ground nuts. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to own a delivery van to ease in transportation and to buy a plot of land to build rental houses. She lives in her own house and the family has access to electricity and does not have access to piped water. Her major expenses include paying for utility bills and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bags of beans, maize and ground nuts.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is 40 years old, married, and supports a family of six. She runs a retail shop in Eldama Ravine town and this has been her income-generating business for the last four years where she gets an average monthly income of KES 20,000.

She has borrowed a second loan of KES 25,000 after successfully paying her previous loan. With this loan, she intends to purchase more items for resale in her shop. She anticipates getting profits, which she will use to expand her business by increase more items to meet her clients' demand.

Pauline hopes to improve her living standards and be financially stable. She also hopes to save money to enable her to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of maize, flour, washing detergents, biscuits and sweets for sale.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 40 years old with one child. She operates a beauty salon to earn a living. She has been in the business for four years and has employed one person. Since she became a client of Faulu Kenya, she has improved her business because she has been trained on business management. She dreams of expanding her business in the future. She has requested for a loan of 40,000 KES to buy hair oil and a dryer.

loans.use: to buy hair oil and a dryer.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Alberta

texts.en:
Alberta is 41 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 10 children.

Alberta is providing motorela, or motorcycle services, with her husband as the driver. She has had this business for six years. She requested a loan for 5,000 PHP to buy tools and pay for gasoline for the services.

Alberta has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Alberta hopes to improve her services.

loans.use: to buy tools and pay for gasoline.

loans.name: Abdusamad

texts.en:
A kind man named Abdusamad lives in a house which is in bad condition. He is married and has three children. His clever children are 11, 12 and 16 years old. Abdusamad’s children want to live in a house in good condition but his income from growing crops is not enough for it. He must repair the bedroom of his children, kitchen and bathroom. He is asking for a loan of 8,000 TJS to buy building materials such as brick, paint, wood, etc., for repairing his house. 
This way, he will make better the quality of his family's living condition. Each month, he will make his payment on time. He awaits your support and mercy. Please, help him and his family if it is possible.

loans.use: to buy building materials as brick and paint for repairing his house.

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Doris is 28 years old and is married with three children who are in school. She operates a grocery store to earn a living. She has been in this business for three years. She operates her business in a competitive environment with frequent customers. Since she became a client of Faulu Kenya, she has improved in the area of savings because she has been trained in financial management. She dreams of expanding her business and buying a piece of land in the future. She has requested a loan of 10,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy fruits and vegetables.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 29 years old. He is married to one wife, Ruth, and they have one child who is two years old. James has been in the business of supplying hardware and building materials for seven years and earns a monthly income of over 50,000 Kenyan shillings (KES).

This will be James's second loan from KADET; he successfully repaid his prior loan. He will use the new loan to purchase hardware supplies and will use the anticipated profits to support his family and develop his future home. His hopes and dreams are to live a successful life and open a big hardware store.

loans.use: to buy hardware materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy tools and pay for gasoline

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Aidah

texts.en:
Aidah is 37 years old and lives in the town of Kireka, in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is married and has 4 children who are all in school. For the past 8 years, Aidah has been working hard to manage her discothèque, where she plays music and provides entertainment.

To help expand her business, Aidah has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more music machines for the disco and will help Aidah generate greater profits, which she will use to pay for school fees. Aidah hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a grocery store.

Aidah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Aidah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more music machines for her discothèque

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en: Gabriel is 62 years old, married with two children. For thirteen years, he has been operating a retail shop to earn a living. Alongside, he runs a transport business to generate more income. He had previously acquired a loan from Faulu Kenya which helped him to add stock to his business. He dreams of operating a wholesale business in the future. Gabriel has requested a loan of 110,000 to buy maize flour, sugar, cooking oil for his shop and kerosene for his vehicle.

loans.use: To buy maize flour, sugar, cooking oil and kerosene.

loans.name: Nelfa

texts.en: Nelfa is 46 years old from Talibon, Bohol. She is married and her husband works as a farmer. She has five children to support out of her business of buying and selling scrap items. She is asking for a loan to buy more scrap items like empty bottles, plastic containers, cans and steels from her community and from the residents in her neighborhood. She hopes that someday, she can make a bigger business out of scraps in order to earn a better income. Her family’s well-being is her main concern and she plans to give her children a good education.

loans.use: to buy more scrap items like empty bottles, plastic containers, cans and steel

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 29 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is married and has 4 children who are all currently in school. For the past 6 years, Sarah has been working hard to manage her salon, where she cuts and styles hair. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stocks of hair gels and creams, and will help Sarah to generate greater profits and allow her to pay for school fees. Sarah hopes that in the future she will be able to open up another salon. 

Sarah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Sarah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of hair gels and creams

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy raw ingredients used in making snacks

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: James

texts.en: James carries out electronics repair and welding to earn a living. He had previously acquired a loan from Faulu Kenya which helped him to buy spare parts and a video recorder for his business. This helped his business to improve and with the income he generated, he was able to support his family. He has requested a loan of 60,000 KES to buy welding machines and wires.

loans.use: To buy wires and welding machines.

loans.name: Nadia

texts.en:
Nadia is 30 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children with 1 of them currently in school. For the past 3 years, Nadia has been working hard to manage her salon, where she cuts and styles hair. 

To help expand her business, Nadia has requested a loan of 3000000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more cosmetics to sell, and will help Nadia to generate greater profits and pay school fees. Nadia hopes that in the future she will be able to open up another salon. 

Nadia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Nadia who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Lena

texts.en:
Lena is 49 years old. She is married and has six children, two of whom are teenagers and currently attending school. Her husband hasn’t worked for a long time now, due to his physical disability, thus, she has been the only provider at home. They live in a town of approximately 30,000 residents in the north-east part of Albania. For the past twenty-something years, Lena has been involved in the livestock business and has also been working for pay at a fish enterprise. “I must work on both to be able to provide for my family,” Lena said. “My daily routine involves around 15 hours of work every day and this tires me, especially now that I am reaching fifty,” she carried on. “One of my youngest children has been accepted to university now, and I’ve got to pay the education fees. This is what makes me keep going…” she said with a vague smile.                              
Lena is requesting a Kiva loan for the first time through VisionFund Albania to add one more milk cow in order to increase milk production. Her promise to all lenders is that she will pay back the loan.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Haide Lita

texts.en:
Haide Lita is 52 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 8 children. 
Haide Lita makes and sells viand, such as adobo, pinakbit and fried chicken. She has had this business for 8 years. She requested a loan for 5,000 to buy raw ingredients used in making viand like vegetables, meat and spices.
Haide Lita is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Haide Lita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients used in making viand (food dish)

loans.name: Gulsara

texts.en:
Gulsara is 58 years old. She is a hard-working woman and tries to be the best in all her deals. She is a widow and has not had any children. With the aim of earning a living she began her own business 2 years ago. She sells a variety of cloth. She keeps and sells her merchandise in a local market. 
This is her second loan with Imon International organization, and she is grateful for its financial support in helping her to realize her plans. She promises to make her payment on time. She awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy cloth to widen her current assortment

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is 20 years old from the town of Talibon, Bohol. 
She is married with one little girl. Ruth and her husband are dependent on their fishing business for an income. Ruth is asking for a loan to buy fishing nets and gasoline, and to pay for boat repair and maintenance. Ruth is determined to be successful in her fishing business so that their child can be well provided for. Her income will be for food, savings and reinvestment in the same business.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets and gasoline, and to pay for boat repair and maintenance

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is 29 years old and lives in the town of Najera in the Kampala West region of Uganda. He is married and has 2 children who are both currently in school. For the past 6 years, Richard has been working hard to manage his poultry business, where he buys young chicks, feeds them and then sells them wholesale. 

To help expand his business, Richard has requested a loan of 3000000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to expand his business by building more structures for his chicks to live in, and will help Richard to generate greater profits and boost his economic status. Richard hopes that in the future he will be able to have a large retail business. 

Richard is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Richard who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to build more structures for his chicks to live in

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy crates of soft drinks to add to his business

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is 34 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 4 children. 
Ruth makes and sells snacks like bibingka or rice cake. She has had this business for 2 years. She requested a loan for 5,000 to buy raw ingredients in making snacks like rice, sugar, cheese and flour.
Ruth has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Ruth hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients used in making snacks

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Francis is a 35-year-old married man. He has 4 children with ages ranging from 5 to 11 years. He describes himself to be a trustworthy, industrious and goal-oriented man. Francis operates a retail store where he sells kerosene and empty bottles. He has been involved in this business for 8 years. His business is located in a fast growing area and his primary customers are regular local residents. Francis describes his biggest business challenge to be insecurity within the area. He will use the Kes 5,800 loan to purchase a solar lantern. His business goal is to expand his business and buy a kerosene pump within 5 years. Francis hopes that in the future, he will have purchased the kerosene pump and bought land with the profits he will have made. Francis had taken a previous loan of Kes 60,000 which he managed to pay back. Besides selling kerosene, he sells maize which increases his income.

loans.use: to buy a solar lantern

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy materials for the expansion of his restaurant and boarding house business

loans.name: Manuel

texts.es: Manuel de 62 años de edad vive con su esposa y sus dos hijos de 12 años de edad que está estudiando en la escuela y de 18 años de edad. Es un hombre muy responsable y honesto con su familia y con el trabajo, ya que trabaja sin descanso para darle lo mejor a sus hijos. Actualmente trabajaba como agricultor de granos básicos y luego vende los frutos de su trabajo para que nunca haga falta el pan a su casa, es muy dedicado a lo que hace y siempre realizándolo de la mejor manera. Se ha visto en la necesidad de pedir ayuda a INTEGRAL para la compra de insumos básicos como semillas, abonos, fertilizantes y esto le servirá para mejorar sus cultivos y cuidarlos de la mejor manera. Agradece de ante mano la ayuda que pronto espera recibir ya que desea entregarle un mejor futuro  para él y su familia.
texts.en: Manuel is 62 years old and he lives with his wife and their two children aged 18 and 12; the younger goes to school. He is a very responsible and honest man, both with his family and in his job, as he works with no rest to give the best to his children. He is a farmer growing basic grains that he then sells in order to provide his family with everything they need. He is greatly dedicated to what he does and he always carries out things in the best way possible. Needing to buy basic supplies such as seeds, manure and fertilizers, he has requested a loan to Integral as this will help him improve his crops and care for them in a better way. He gives thanks in advance for the help he hopes to receive, as he wants to grant a better future to his family and to himself.

loans.use: To buy seeds, manure and fertilizers.

loans.name: Virgilio

texts.es: Virgilio vive con su familia su esposa y sus hijos en casa propia. Es un hombre que se caracteriza por ser muy amigable, atento, servicial, honesto y sincero. Don Virgilio trabaja como jornalero en un terreno donde cultiva los principales granos básicos como frijoles, arroz u otros y así estos los vende para siempre llevar el pan a su casa.  Se ha visto en la necesidad de pedir ayuda ya que necesita insumos agrícolas para su cosecha él es de pocos recursos y no tiene lo suficiente para comprarlos por el mismo, es por eso que solicita a INTEGRAL un préstamo para la compra abonos, semillas, insecticidas etc. Esta seguro que con la ayuda recibida su cosecha mejorara y poco a poco les seguirá entregando un mejor futuro a sus hijos y a su esposa.
texts.en: Virgilio lives in his own house with his wife and children. He is a very friendly, caring, helpful, honest and sincere man. Virgilio is a farmer, working every day on his land where he grows main basic grains such ash beans, rice and others. He sells these products to provide for his family. Needing agricultural supplies for his crops, he has decided to ask for help as he is not very rich and he does not have enough money to buy them on his own. For this reason he has asked INTEGRAL for a loan to buy manure, seeds, insecticides and other supplies. He is sure that he will succeed in improving his harvest thanks to the help he is receiving, and that little by little he will be able to provide a better future to his wife and children.

loans.use: To buy manure, seeds, insecticides and other supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy raw ingredients used in making snacks

loans.name: Mable

texts.en:
Mable is 47 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past 10 years, Mable has been working hard to manage her grocery, where she sells general foods like eggs and water. 

To help expand her business, Mable has requested a loan of 2500000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stock like bread and oil to sell, and will help Mable to generate greater profits, grow her business and attract more customers. Mable hopes that in the future she will be able to start selling bananas. 

Mable is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mable who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more stock like bread and oil to sell

loans.name: Odgerel

texts.en:
Odgerel is 33 years old and lives with her mother and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her family lives in a small house, in the outer ger housing districts of the city. Odgerel’s mother is retired and stays at home, while Odgerel's daughter attends secondary school. 

Odgerel supports her family by operating a clothing retail stall at the largest outdoor market in Mongolia. In 2006, when she first began her business, she sold only leather belts and traditional Mongolian fabric belts. In the beginning stages of her business, she rented a stall at the present market from another person who had a rental contract with the market. This was an unstable business situation for her because the middleman could dismiss her at any time. At the time her stall had 1 million MNT in working capital. Usually, it is very difficult to obtain a rental contract with Narantuul because the stalls are in such high demand. 

At this time of year, it is the high shopping season, since it's new school year beginning time, so Odgerel wants to use this loan to help support her in this very busy shopping season of the year. Odgerel's business goal is to one day operate her own clothing shop. Odgerel also said, "It's my personal goal to support my mother and daughter so they can live happily."

loans.use: to purchase more clothing products to sell in order to increase her income

loans.name: San's Group

texts.en:
A villager from a rural area of Pusat province, San, aged 53, is a widowed mother with five children, who works as a farmer. For almost thirty years, San has been struggling to feed her children through farming rice and therefore she supplements her income by selling Vietnamese pan cakes. From the current business, she is able to earn about 10,000 KHR per day and manages to save around 5,000 KHR. 

San has been with VisionFund for four loan cycles while the other members in her group are new to VisionFund. The previous loans have allowed San to buy fertilizers for her rice paddy and ingredients for making Vietnamese pan cakes for selling. San, after successfully paying back all her previous loans, is leading a group of three female members to apply for another loan from VisionFund. As the group leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland. From this loan, San hopes that her crops will produce a better and higher yield so that she can sell them for good money and as a result her family can live in better conditions.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland

loans.name: Samoert's Group

texts.en: Samoert is 35 years old and also a mother of three dependent kids, some of whom are still in school. Her entire family is residing in the Kror Lanh district of Siem Reap Province. For her children's sake, she earns a living through rice farming as the main source of income. She also gets further income from her pig-raising business. She is able to earn about 16,000 KHR per day from the current business that she has been with for six years. Samoert took the first loan with VisionFund in 2011 and has paid it back already. The loan has successfully enabled her to manage her household well, as well as to keep her children in school. Now, she forms a group of two members to apply for a new loan. She is applying for 1,200,000 KHR while her fellow group member is asking for 1,000,000 KHR. As the group leader, she will use her loan portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland and pig feed for her pig-raising business. She hopes to gain more crop output, so she can better her standard of living and keep her children in school until tertiary level.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and fertilizer for her farmland

location.town: Siem Reap Province, Kror Lanh district

loans.name: Altankhuyag

texts.en:
Altankhuyag is 24 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His family lives in a small house. Both he and his wife support their life by operating a beauty salon business.

With this loan of 2,600,000 MNT, Altankhuyag will purchase beautician equipment which can remove freckles and tattoos and clean facial skin. The loan will hopefully allow him to expand his service offerings and give higher quality services with better equipment than he currently owns. The salon’s extra earnings will go towards his family’s expenses and reaching his family’s goal of being secure in their living condition.

loans.use: to purchase beautician equipment for his beauty salon

loans.name: Courage Group

texts.en: Thanks to the loan you gave to members of the "Courage" group; their businesses and personal lives have improved tremendously as a result of the continued support they have received from you. With your previous loan, their business inventories increased, which led to an increase in sales and profit for these borrowers. Having repaid the previous loan successfully, they are again requesting a new loan of 1,500,000 for each to further improve on their businesses. Mohamed is the current leader of the group. He is 32 years of age. A native of Makeni, he is married and has two children who are attending primary schools. Mohamed sells used clothes and has been in this business for many years now. He has requested this loan to buy bales of used clothes to add to his current stock. Used clothes are very popular among Sierra Leoneans. Since the majority cannot buy ready-to-wear-clothes, they rely on cheap imported second-hand clothes for their clothing needs.

loans.use: To expand the inventory of his used clothes stock

loans.name: Shazia's Group

texts.en:
Saiqa, a 31-year-old woman, is a mother of 3 sons and 2 daughters, living in one of the poorly developed area of Rawalpindi, Pakistan. Her husband has been running a general store since 2009 and wants to expand it by buying more goods, but because of financial constraints he finds this difficult. 

For that, Saiqa, as a member of 2 person lending group, has requested a loan from KIVA partner BRAC Pakistan, for the growth of her husband's general store. This will help in increasing their monthly savings and improving their children's future as well. She is hopeful that the loan will result in a positive and productive outcome for them so that they can lead a happy life.

loans.use: To expand her husband's general store.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is 38 years old. She is married to Boniface and together they have four children aged between three to 15 years, all school-going.


Salome has been in the clothes-selling business for four years and currently earns KES.15,000. The loan will be used to buy more stocks of clothes for resale. The anticipated profits will be used to expand her business and pay school fees for her children.


This is Salome's second loan term with KADET LTD, and she has paid the previous one back successfully. Her hopes and dreams are to provide quality education for her children and to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Kim's Group

texts.en: Kim is 44 years old and lives in a rural area of the Bakan district, Pursat province. She has four children, two (one daughter and one son) of whom are dependent on her and are helping in the family business. Kim and her husband have been rice farming on five hectares of farmland for twenty years to make a living. The low crop yields due to insect damage is still the main challenge for her. This is the first microloan for Kim’s group, consisting of four members, with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. Now leading her group to apply for a loan, as the group leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her income so as to improve her living status.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farmland

loans.name: Sa Ran

texts.en:
Sa Ran (in the photo) is 55 years old while his wife, Samon, is 41, and they live in a suburb of Phnom Penh. They have six children -- four sons and two daughters. Two are married and live separately, one is a driver, two attend school and another is helping with her parents in the business.

Sa Ran’s family has two lines of business (1) raising pigs and (2) producing rice wine. He is asking for his first loan in the amount of $1,000 to assist in his pig farming by buying a feed pig.

loans.use: to buy a feed pig.

loans.name: Khorn's Group

texts.en: Khorn, 32, is one of the breadwinners of a family with dependent children: a daughter and three sons. All of his children are still in school. He and his wife have struggled in supporting the big household via growing paddy rice on one hectare of farmland. Besides this primary source of income, Khorn also makes bamboo baskets for extra income. Having been in these businesses for eight years, he can earn about 18,000 KHR per day. Khorn's group consists of two members; they have been with VisionFund for seven cycles and have successfully paid back the loans. The past loans have made Khorn run both his businesses properly and have relieved his family's burden. Now he and his fellow group member are seeking a new loan. As the leader, Khorn will use his portion to buy 5 sacks of fertilizer for his rice field and a portion of it to buy more bamboo in order to make more baskets for sale. He hopes to double his income, so he can set aside some money to buy a plot of land to expand his rice farming business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for his rice field and materials for making baskets

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkul Borey District

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria is a married woman. She has 3 children with ages ranging from 5 to 16 years. She describes herself to be an honest woman. She operates a tailoring retail store where she sells the clothes she makes. She has been involved in this business for a year. In addition, Victoria does farming where she sells vegetables. Her business is located within a busy area and her primary customers are daily local residents from the local area. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the high cost of transportation charged when getting clothes materials from outside sources. She will use the Kes 8,700 loan to purchase a water tank for her household use and the family. Her business goal is to run a big boutique within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will be a great business lady in her home town.

loans.use: to buy a water tank

loans.name: Amir

texts.en:
Amir is 32 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala South region of Uganda. He is married and has 2 children with 1 of them currently in school. For the past 5 years, Amir has been working hard to manage his produce market stall, which sells maize, cassava and potatoes. 

To help expand his business, Amir has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stocks of vegetables to sell, and will help Amir to generate greater profits and increase his income. Amir hopes that in the future he will be able to own a wholesale shop. 

Amir is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Amir who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of vegetables to sell

loans.name: Mahmurod

texts.en:
Mahmurod is married and the father of 4 children. He works as an engineer in a factory. He has a little income. It does not allow him to provide for the needs of his family and repair his house because his family is large and needs to live in a big and comfortable house. This year he is going to repair his house with modern planning. Also he plans to change the windows and doors. 
This loan will help him to buy building materials to repair the house. In this way he will provide a higher quality of living for his family and put an end to the problems with the house.

loans.use: To buy doors, windows and paint for repairing his house

loans.name: Battulga

texts.en:
Mr. Battulga is 50 years old and lives with his wife, Tumendemberel, and two children in the Govi-Altai province of Mongolia. 

His wife helps his business and his children go to the college. He worked in a private company as a civil assistant engineer for 30 years. 

He has just started a grocery store business. But he lacks working capital, so he needs 2000,000 MNT to purchase goods for his grocery business.

Mr. Battulga is a hardworking and tidy man. He said, "My business efficiency and profit is produced by expanding the grocery store business and improving my life." Now his business is sustainable and has many regular customers.

loans.use: To purchase goods for his grocery business

loans.name: Sokhea's Group

texts.en: Sokhea is a 26-year-old mother of one daughter who is still in school; her entire family is living in a rural village in the Kror Kor District of Pursat Province, Cambodia. To make a living, she and her husband have been farming rice on three hectares of farmland for several years. The current business earns her about 10,000 KHR per day and she manages to save about 5,000 KHR each day. The main challenge for her business is low crop yield resulting from the drought. Sokhea’s group consists of three members. She is the group leader, and a first time borrower with Kiva’s partner, VisonFund. Now leading her group to apply for loan, Sokhea will use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to earn more income from the crop yield so as to set aside some money to have a decent motor vehicle for commuting and to keep her child in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland.

loans.name: Oeurm's Group

texts.en:
Originally from the Pursat province of the Bakan district of Cambodia, Oeurm is 54 years old. She is a married mother of four children, one daughter of whom is still dependent on her and in school. 

To support her family, she has been planting paddy rice for twenty years; her husband also helps her to generate additional income as a palm juice maker. 

Together, they are able to earn about KHR 10,000 per day to meet the family’s needs. Low crop yield is still the main challenge for her paddy field business. 

Oeurm’s group consisted of three members as first time borrowers with VisionFund. Now, she is leading her group to request a new loan. As the leader, Oeurm is going to use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland. 

She hopes to earn more income from her crop yields, so as to make a good living and keep her child in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland

loans.name: Ly's Group

texts.en:
A widow from a rural village located in the Bakan District of Pursat Province, Ly is aged 52-years old and has only one son, who is working to support her business. Rice farming is the main source of her family's income; she has been in this business for more than ten years and earns about 20,800 KHR per day to support her living. The lack of water is the main challenge for her family's business.

This is the first micro loan for Ly's group of four members all of whom live in the same village. She is leading other group members to apply for a loan of 1,000,000 KHR each. She will use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland. She hopes to make more rice to increase her family's income to make a better living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland.

loans.name: Xatgul

texts.en: Xatgul is a 50-year-old wonam and the lovely mother of three children. She is a hard-working businesswoman who runs a clothing business. Xatgul offers dresses, pants, and underwear. Xatgul has been operating the business for last five years. This is her first loan from AqroInvest and Kiva. She plans to use the loan to buy more clothing material.  The extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her standard of living. In the future, Xatgul plans to enlarge her store.

loans.use: to buy more clothing material.

loans.name: Thea's Group

texts.en:
A citizen from a rural area located in the Kror Kor district of Pursat province, Thea is 29 years old. She is a married woman with three dependent children, two daughters and one son; all of her children are still in school. 

She and her husband have been involved in rice farming on 1.5 hectares of farmland and sugar palm making for several years. Together, they can earn about 10,000 KHR and manage to save about 4,000 KHR each day after daily expenses. 

Thea has been with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund, for one cycle and she completely paid back the loan; while her group members have been with VisionFund for two cycles. The first loan has helped her to support her business. Now she is leading her group of three female members to apply for a new loan. 

As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland and use a portion of it to pay a harvesting fee. She hopes to earn a better income, so as to improve her lifestyle and keep her children in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland

loans.name: Mom's Group

texts.en:
Mom is 30 years old and married. She lives with her husband and two children, one son and one daughter, both of whom are living at home and still in school in a rural village located in the Kror kor district, Cambodia. 

She has been in rice farming on two hectares of farmland for 11 years and supplements the family’s income by raising chickens, while her husband is a paid worker in a local area. Low crop yield is the main challenge for her business.

This is the fourth loan for Mom’s group with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. Her group consists of three members. The past loans have helped her relieve the family’s burden and improve their livelihood. 

She and her group members are applying for a new loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to earn a better income, which will improve their standard of living and keep her children in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland

loans.name: Norng's Group

texts.en: A resident from a rural village in the Sangke District of Battambang Province of Cambodia, Norng is a 54-year old married mother of four children. The main sources of the family’s income are from rice farming and cassava planting; these are the businesses that she and her husband have been operating  for almost 30 years. The current business earns her approximately KHR 20,000 per day. Low crop yield is still the main challenge for her business. This is the sixth loan for Norng while the other members are in their third cycle. They successfully paid back the loan with VisionFund, which has improved her standard of living gradually. Now, she is leading her group to seek a new loan. She and her members are applying for KHR 1,400,000 each. As the leader, Norng will use her portion to buy fertilizer and seeds for her farmland and use a portion of it to pay labor costs. She hopes to earn more income to set aside some money to purchase piglets for raising to earn extra income.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland.

loans.name: Ly's Group

texts.en:
Living in a wooden house located in a village of the Kror Kor District of Pursat Province, Ly is a 32-year-old mother of two children, who are dependents and still in school. To make a living, she sells some groceries in the village while her husband is paid worker to help support the family. Sometimes, she works for others for a fee to better support her family. She has been in this business for several years. The current business earns her about 20,000 KHR per day and she is able to save about 12,000 KHR each day after expenses. 

Ly's group consists of two members who live in the same village; she is the seventh cycled client while her member is just started with VisionFund. The past loans that she completely paid back have helped her better support her business and improve her livelihood. Now, she is leading her group to apply for a loan with VisionFund. She will use her portion to buy a motorbike for her family to support her current business. With this loan, she hopes to increase her family's income and enable her husband to save some time to better care the children.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her family to support her current business.

loans.name: Te's Group

texts.en:
A villager from Pusat province, Te, aged 46, is married and has nine children. Two of her children stay with the family, and one is a student while the other one works for other for money. Te is a housewife and her husband is the one who earns money to support the family by farming rice, selling palm juice, and sometimes working as a laborer. Her family has always wanted to have a proper house, yet they lack money. 

Te's group consists of three members and she was appointed to be a group leader. Te and the other member have been with VisionFund for two loan cycles. As a leader, Te used her portion to buy fertilizers and use a share of it to pay for labor fees as she hired some people to help with the land preparation and cultivating. Through this loan, Te hopes to increase her crop yield so that she can make more money for her family to live in a better standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and spend on labor fees.

loans.name: Maria De Los Angeles

texts.es: Maria de los Ángeles  de 45 años de edad , casada, con 4 hijos mayores de edad, tiene por negocio una pulpería y billares ubicado  en su casa de habitación , años de tener el negocio 10 años, en la actualidad Maria de los Ángeles es una persona muy luchadora, la cual se levanta temprano día a día para salir adelante con su negocio y poder ver ingresos del mismo, esta emprendedora esta solicitando el financiamiento para la compra de productos de consumo diario como: arroz, azúcar, frijoles, aceite, pan, leche, huevos, leña, condimentos, hielos, jugos naturales los cuales ofrece a los habitante de su barrio.
texts.en: Maria de los Ángeles is 45 and is married with four grown-up children. She runs a convenience store and a billiard room from her home. She has been in business for ten years now and is a very hard-working woman. Maria gets up early day after day in order to make sure that her business grows and her income increases. This entrepreneur is applying for a loan so that she can buy basic products such as rice, sugar, beans, oil, bread, milk, eggs,  firewood, condiments, ice and fruit juices, all of which she will sell to customers from the local neighbourhood.

loans.use: to buy basic products such as rice, sugar, beans, oil, bread, milk, eggs,  firewood, condiments, ice and fruit juices, all of which she will sell to customers from the local neighbourhood.

loans.name: Lun's Group

texts.en:
A citizen from a village located in the Mongkul Borey district, Lun is 43-years old and married. She lives with her husband and her children doing rice farming to make a living. She has eight children; five of whom are dependent on her and still in school. Having been in the rice farming business for eight years, she is able to earn about 20,000 KHR per day. 

Lun has been with VisionFund for six loan cycles while the other member has been with VisionFund for two cycles. After successful loans from VisionFund, she feels empowered to make a living. She is leading a group of two to apply for a loan with VisionFund. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to grow her rice healthily so as to improve her living condition.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland.

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkul Borey District

loans.name: Chantho's Group

texts.en:
Aged 48, Chantho is a rice farmer from Banteay Meanchey Province's Mongkul Borey District, Cambodia. She is a married mother of five children; two daughters and three sons, who are still in school. She has been in rice farming for seven years earning about 18,000 KHR per day, but is able to save only about 4,000 KHR each day.

Chantho's group consists of three members and she is the leader of this group. She has been with VisionFund for three cycles and successfully paid back the loans. Now, requesting a loan with VisionFund, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers and use a portion of it to spend on land plowing. She hopes to make more rice to earn more income to set aside some money for house improvement.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and use a portion of it to spend for land plowing

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkul Borey District

loans.name: Annapurna Baba Nilakantheswar Shg Group

texts.en:
In 2009, 12 women from Jagannathpur Patna village stepped out and decided to build a secured future for their family and formed a group named Annapurna Baba Nilakantheswar Self Help Group (named after Lord Shiva, who they believe will protect them). The members of Annapurna Baba Nilakantheswar Self Help Group are all women from the district of Khurda in Odisha, India. One of them is Mrs. Kabita, who was selected as their secretary. The lady in the red saree standing to the extreme left in the photo is Kabita.

Kabita is 35 years old and is staying with her husband and her 12-year-old son. Her husband has been involved in vegetable and paddy farming for a long time. She got the idea of doing vegetable cultivation from her husband, so she gathered some other women from her neighborhood and told them about her plan. They liked her idea and appreciated her. She took the leadership of the group and started to cultivate vegetables and sell them in her village. She took some land for lease and started vegetable cultivation on a small scale. She started with a limited supply of vegetables like tomatoes and potatoes and grew to sell more than seven varieties like brinjal (eggplant), cucumbers, beans, carrots, and radishes. She has developed a very good relationship with her customers in the village as she sells fresh and high-quality vegetables. She likes the fact that she can cater to the needs of the people in her village.
  
Now she has a new idea of doing sugarcane cultivation, for which she has requested a loan to utilize for the resources necessary to do sugarcane cultivation. A portion of the loan amount will help her to purchase sugarcane plants, fertilizers, and insecticides, and to cover operational expenses like labor charges.

loans.use: to pay for resources like sugarcane plants, fertilizers, and insecticides for her sugarcane plantation.

loans.name: Dinabandhu

texts.en:
Dinabandhu is a 47-year-old differently abled person living with his wife and two sons aged 11 and 13 in Odisha, India. He owns a variety-cum-betel store in his village. He sells pan, biscuits, hair oil, talcum powder, soaps, chocolates, and other daily household consumables.

His family lives on 5,000 INR per month currently and Dinabandhu wants to earn more for the betterment of his family. He has requested a loan of 20,000 INR to buy a greater variety of stock of what he is selling right now and to offer a better quality and range of products to his customers. He wishes to send his children to a better school and see them well educated. He thanks all who support him.

loans.use: To buy more stock and add more products to his variety store

loans.name: Bishnuprasad

texts.en:
Bishnuprasad is a differently abled 20-year-old single man. He lives with his parents and elder brother. His brother works away from home and he has to support his parents. He lives in Odisha, India.
Bishnuprasad has been operating a small bicycle repair store, which is the only source of income for the family and a profitable project, but also not enough to cover all the costs and the family's needs. His monthly income is 3,000 INR.
He currently has the skills and equipment to do good repairs and replacements, but he does not have the required spare parts for replacements. He has to travel almost 15 miles for a good spare part.
He is requesting a loan of 30,000 INR to cover the costs of purchasing necessary spare parts used for repairing of bicycles as well as motorbikes. This will provide Bishnuprasad with a varied collection of spare parts, which will help to increase his income and improve the family's living standards.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts used for repairing of bicycles as well as motorbikes for his repair shop

loans.name: Sushama

texts.en:
Sushama is a 40-year-old widowed woman. She got married to Mr. Basanta in 1995. She was happy with her children and her husband, a tractor driver. After 14 years of marriage, she lost her husband due to a cardiac arrest episode. At that time, she had a son aged eight years and a daughter aged five years. 

She has been struggling since then to support her family. She started a snack and tea stall at her house, which is located quite close to the market. She cooks and sells local snacks and tea in the mornings and evenings, the general hours for such a business. She sells pan at a small scale during the rest of the day to fill her day and support her income. She hopes for a bright future for her children. 

With the three years of experience in running the shop, she wants to expand her business to meet customer demand. She needs a loan of 30,000 INR to buy some utensils and stock up on raw materials like besan and oil for cooking her snacks, as well as buy new products like packaged snacks and wafers to stock in her betel shop. She also plans to buy some furniture to seat her customers as she sees an increase in her customer base. She says that the increased cash flow can change her life and provide better education to her children.

loans.use: to pay for benches to seat her customers and to buy utensils and raw materials like besan and oil in bulk for her snack stall

loans.name: Jemamani

texts.en:
Jemamani is a 39-year-old differently abled woman living with her mother, elder brother, and sister-in-law. She has a goat farm in which she currently has 10 goats. She purchases goat kids and sells them for meat to the local butcher shops when they grow. It takes 8 to 9 months for her to raise and sell them. She goes out in the morning to leave the goats for grazing in the fields and returns by noon. She then helps her sister-in-law in the household activities and then resumes taking care of her goats by feeding them at home. Her brother assists her in selling and maintaining these goats. In this way, she is earning to control her cash flow, which is not sufficient to manage her daily activities.

She says that there is a lot of demand during the months of April-July and October-December, the auspicious time for Indian weddings. Currently, she is not able to meet the demand during these months and other peak demand times.
